revision.text:
{{Infobox building |name = 383 Madison Avenue |image = 383 Madison Ave Bear Stearns C R Flickr 1.jpg |image_size = |caption = 383 Madison Avenue at night | alternate_names = {{unbulleted list |Bear Stearns Building }} |location = 383 Madison Avenue, [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | map_type = Manhattan#New York City#New York#USA |status = Completed |start_date = 1999 |completion_date = 2001 |opening = 2002 |building_type = Commercial Office |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|230|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} |top_floor = |floor_count = 47 |elevator_count = |cost = |floor_area = {{convert|1200000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} |architect = [[David Childs]] ([[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]]) |structural_engineer= [[WSP Group|WSP Cantor Seinuk]] |main_contractor = [[Turner Construction Company]] |developer = |owner = [[JP Morgan Chase]] |management = |references = }}
'''383 Madison Avenue''' is an office building owned and occupied by [[JP Morgan Chase]] in [[New York City]] on a full block bound by [[Madison Avenue]] and [[Vanderbilt Avenue]] between East 46th and 47th Streets. Formerly known as the '''Bear Stearns Building''', it housed the world headquarters of the now-defunct [[Bear Stearns]] from the building's completion until Bear's collapse and sale to JPMorgan Chase in 2008. The building now houses the New York offices for [[J.P. Morgan & Co.|J.P. Morgan's investment banking division]], which formerly occupied [[277 Park Avenue]]. Both 383 Madison and 277 Park are adjacent to JPMorgan Chase's world headquarters at [[270 Park Avenue]]. The building changed hands in 2008 during JP Morgan's takeover of Bear Stearns. On their second-quarter 2008 conference call, JP Morgan estimated the building's value at $1.1 to $1.4 billion.
A night time photograph of the building taken at a steep angle from its base appears on the cover of [[William D. Cohan]]'s book, ''[[House of Cards (Cohan book)|House of Cards: A Tale of Hubris and Wretched Excess on Wall Street]]'' (2009).
==Architecture and design== Designed by [[David Childs]] of [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] LLP, it is 755 ft (230 m) tall with 47 floors. [[Hines Interests]] managed the development process for Bear Stearns. It was completed in 2001 and opened in 2002, at which time it was, by some reports, the 88th tallest building in the world. The building has approximately 110,000 rentable square meters (1,200,000 sq ft).
The building has an [[octagon]]al tower that rises out of a rectangular base to a 20 m (70 ft) crown made of glass which is illuminated at night.
The building's visually decorative design differs from the conventional functionalist style of neighboring office buildings, and hence has proven unpopular with some critics. ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' said, "This is a building you wouldn't want to get anywhere near at a cocktail party. Dressed nearly head to toe in dour granite, and geometrically proper, it's stiff to the point of pass-out boredom. Out of character with SOM's (Skidmore, Owings & Merrill's) current work, the design recalls the firm's unfortunate postmodern interlude a decade ago."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyorkmetro.com/nymetro/arts/architecture/reviews/5815/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051112201126/http://newyorkmetro.com/nymetro/arts/architecture/reviews/5815/ |archivedate=2005-11-12 |df= }}</ref>
A 72-story tower proposed by [[G Ware Travelstead]] for the site during the 1980s was never built. The building (also being referred as Travelstead Tower<ref>http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=8332</ref>) was designed by [[Kohn Pedersen Fox]].
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px"> Image:BearStearns.JPG|Note the glass "crown" at top </gallery>

__NOTOC__ {{refimprove|date=August 2013}} [[File:Third Street Los Angeles.jpg|thumb|350px|3rd Street in Los Angeles between [[La Cienega Boulevard]] and [[Fairfax Avenue]] is known for its shops and eateries]] [[File:Farmers Market Los Angeles.JPG|thumb|[[Farmers Market (Los Angeles)|Farmers Market]] on 3rd Street and [[Fairfax Avenue]]]] '''3rd Street''' in [[Los Angeles]] is a major east–west thoroughfare. The west end is in downtown [[Beverly Hills, California|Beverly Hills]] by [[Santa Monica Boulevard]], and the east is at [[Alameda Street]] in [[Downtown Los Angeles|downtown]] Los Angeles, where it shares a one-way couplet with 4th Street. East of Alameda it becomes 4th Street, where it heads to [[East Los Angeles, California|East Los Angeles]], where it turns back into 3rd Street upon crossing Indiana Street. 3rd Street eventually becomes Pomona Boulevard in [[Monterey Park, California|Monterey Park]], where it then turns into Potrero Grande Drive and finally turns into Rush Street in [[Rosemead, California|Rosemead]] and ends in [[El Monte, California|El Monte]].<ref name="Map">[https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Main+Street+and+3rd+Street,+Los+Angeles&sll=34.053299,-118.243425&sspn=0.00784,0.015836&ie=UTF8&ll=34.04953,-118.24585&spn=0.00784,0.015836&t=h&z=16&iwloc=addr=map&ct=image Exact location of East 3rd Street in Downtown Los Angeles]</ref>
3rd Street passes along the south side of [[The Grove (Los Angeles)|The Grove]] and "The Original" Farmers Market at [[Fairfax Avenue]], near the headquarters of The [[Writers Guild of America, west|Writers Guild of America]], West. There are also many other restaurants, [[boutiques]], and antique stores on this specific strip of 3rd Street, which is less upscale and more relaxed than nearby [[Robertson Boulevard]] and [[Melrose Avenue]].<ref>{{Citation |last=Zappa |first=Moon Unit |title=ONE STREET AT A TIME; Positively Third Street |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B03E6D91338F93BA25752C1A9679C8B63 |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=2001-11-18}}</ref>
3rd Street is parallel to two other major thoroughfares, [[Wilshire Boulevard]] to the south and [[Beverly Boulevard]] to the north. It is four lanes wide east of [[Doheny Drive]], and it passes through the same communities as Wilshire Boulevard.
==Located on 3rd Street==
From east to west: * [[Bradbury Building]] * [[Million Dollar Theater]] * [[St. Vincent Medical Center (Los Angeles)|St. Vincent Medical Center]] * [[Marlborough School (Los Angeles)|Marlborough School]] * [[Yeshiva Aharon Yaakov-Ohr Eliyahu]] (formerly [[Daniel Murphy High School]]) * [[Park La Brea, Los Angeles|Park La Brea]] * [[Farmers Market (Los Angeles)|Farmers Market]] and [[The Grove at Farmers Market|The Grove]] * [[Writers Guild of America, West]] * [[Joan's on Third]] * [[Beverly Center]] * [[Cedars-Sinai Medical Center]] * [[Little Bangladesh]]
==Education and transportation== [[File:LAUSD HQ Bldg.jpg|thumb|Headquarters building of LAUSD in Downtown Los Angeles]]
* [[Los Angeles Unified School District|Los Angeles Board of Education Headquarters]] * [[List of Los Angeles Unified School District schools#Elementary schools|Evelyn Thurman Gratts Elementary School]], 3rd Street and Lucas Avenue * [[Miguel Contreras Learning Complex]], 3rd Street and Lucas Avenue * [[Metro Local]] bus lines 16, 17 and 316 serve west 3rd Street. [[Montebello Transit]] line 40 serves east 3rd Street.
The [[Gold Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Gold Line]] runs on 3rd Street between [[Indiana (Los Angeles Metro station)|Indiana Street]] and [[Atlantic (Los Angeles Metro station)|Atlantic Boulevard]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==

{{About|a politician of Imperial Russia|a modern Russian politician with this name|Aleksandr Konovalov (politician, born 1968)}} [[Image:Alexander Konovalov.jpeg|thumb|right|Aleksandr Konovalov.]] '''Aleksandr Ivanovich Konovalov''' ({{lang-ru|Алекса́ндр Ива́нович Конова́лов}}) (17 September 1875, [[Moscow]] – 28 January 1949, [[Paris]], [[France]]; [[Sainte-Geneviève-des-Bois Cemetery]]) was a [[Russia]]n [[Constitutional Democratic Party|Kadet]] politician and entrepreneur. One of Russia's biggest textile manufacturers, he became a leader of the liberal, business-oriented [[Progressive Party (Russia)|Progressist Party]] and was a member of the Progressive Bloc in the [[Fourth Duma]].
==Biography== During [[World War I]] he was vice president of [[Alexander Guchkov]]'s Military-Industrial Committee, and after the [[February Revolution]] he became Minister of Trade and Industry in the [[Russian Provisional Government|Provisional Government]]. He was an active member of the irregular [[freemasonic]] lodge, the [[Grand Orient of Russia’s Peoples]].<ref name="mason"> {{cite news |url= http://freemasonry.bcy.ca/texts/russia/russian_masons.html |title= Noteworthy members of the Grand Orient of France in Russia and the Supreme Council of the Grand Orient of Russia’s People |date= 15 October 2017 |work= Grand Lodge of British Columbia and Yukon |page= }}</ref> After the [[October Revolution]] he emigrated to [[France]], where he was a leader of leftist Russian émigrés; at the start of [[World War II]] he moved to the [[United States]].
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9046019/Aleksandr-Ivanovich-Konovalov Encyclopædia Britannica] * [http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/konovalov.html Biographies with pictures] (Russian) * Michael T. Florinsky (ed.), ''McGraw-Hill Encyclopedia of Russia and the Soviet Union'' (1961), p. 284.

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Alfred Beit<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | image = Alfred Beit00.jpg<!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = Alfred Beit, by [[Giovanni Boldini]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1853|2|15}} | birth_place = [[Hamburg]], [[German Confederation]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1906|7|16|1853|2|15}} | death_place = [[Tewin]], Hertfordshire | nationality = British | networth = £8,050,000<ref name="jewishtopwealth">{{cite journal |last1=Rubinstein |first1=William |title=Jewish top wealth-holders in Britain, 1809–1909 |journal=Jewish Historical Studies |date=2001 |volume=37 |page=135 |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/29780032 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |via=[[JSTOR]] |registration=yes }}</ref> | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = }}
'''Alfred Beit''' (15 February 1853 – 16 July 1906) was a British gold and diamond magnate in South Africa, and a major donor and profiteer of infrastructure development on the African continent. He also donated much money to university education and research in several countries, and was the "silent partner" who structured the capital flight from post-Boer War South Africa to [[Rhodesia (region)|Rhodesia]], and the [[Rhodes Scholarship]], named after his employee, [[Cecil Rhodes]].
== Life and career == [[Image:Laura Beit00.jpg|thumb|left|Mrs Laura Beit (Alfred and Otto Beit's mother), by [[Leopold Graf von Kalckreuth|Leopold von Kalckreuth]]]] Born and brought up in [[Hamburg]], [[German Confederation|Germany]], he was the eldest son and second of six children of an affluent Jewish-German citizen of Hamburg. His younger siblings included [[Otto Beit]]. Alfred Beit was an unpromising scholar and was apprenticed to [[Jules Porgès]] & Cie, the Amsterdam diamond firm where he developed a talent for examining stones.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |first=Martin |last=Meredith |title=Diamonds, Gold, and War: The British, the Boers, and the Making of South Africa |location=New York |publisher=PublicAffairs |year=2007 |isbn=9781586484736 }}</ref>
Beit made his first fortune in property speculation. Responding to a demand for business premises, he bought a piece of land and built twelve corrugated iron sheds for offices and rented eleven out monthly and kept one for himself. Twelve years later he sold the land for a considerable profit.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
Beit was sent to [[Kimberley, South Africa]] in 1875 by his firm to buy diamonds—following the diamond strike at Kimberley. He became a business friend of [[Cecil Rhodes]] through his role in the Kimberley Central Company. Beit was captivated by Rhodes' talk of 'big schemes'.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> Together, they proceeded to buy out digging ventures and to eliminate opposition such as [[Barney Barnato]]. He rapidly became one of a group of financiers who gained control of the diamond-mining claims in the Central, Dutoitspan, and [[De Beers]] mines. Rhodes was the active politician and Beit provided a lot of the planning and financial backing.
Beit's diamond interests were mainly concentrated on Kimberley mine. He focused his main attention on the Kimberley Central Company aiming to expand its interests. He had a major role in the rise of Kimberley Central Company.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
In 1886 Beit extended his interests to the newly discovered goldfields of the [[Witwatersrand]] and met with great success. In his business ventures there he made use of financiers [[Hermann Eckstein]] and [[Joseph Benjamin Robinson|Sir Joseph Robinson]]. He founded the Robertson Syndicate and the firm of Wernher, Beit & Co. He imported mining engineers from the USA and was among the first to adopt deep-level mining. Rhodes purportedly was granted concessions by [[Lobengula]], as a result of which Beit founded the [[British South Africa Company]] in 1888.
Beit became life-governor of De Beers and also a director of numerous other companies such as Rand Mines, Rhodesia Railways and the Beira Railway Company.
In 1888 Beit moved to London when he felt he was better able to manage his financial empire and support Rhodes in his Southern African ambitions. Beit moved into Tewin Water, [[Tewin]], near [[Welwyn]], a large Regency house with Victorian additions and 7,000 acres (28 km²), and a few miles away [[Julius Wernher]] bought [[Luton Hoo]], with 5,218 acres (21.1 km²). In the 1890s, he had a mansion built in [[Park Lane]] – [[Aldford House]].
Inspired by Rhodes' imperialist vision,{{citation needed|date=September 2008}} he took part in the planning and financing of the unsuccessful [[Jameson Raid]] of late 1895 which was intended to trigger a coup in the [[South African Republic]] in the Transvaal. As a result of this debacle, Rhodes resigned as Prime Minister, and both he and Beit were found guilty by the House of Commons inquiry. Beit was obliged to resign as director of the Charter Company, but was elected vice-president of the British South Africa Company a few years later. With the death of Rhodes in 1902, Beit, as one of the trustees, helped control the enormous estate, currently being helped by the [[Oppenheimer]] family of [[De Beers]] and [[Anglo American plc|Anglo-American]].
Beit never married and had no children. He died at Tewin Water on 16 July 1906 after seeing a rapid deterioration in his health. He left an estate of £8,049,886 (equivalent to £{{Inflation|UK-GDP|0.008049886|1906|r=2}} billion in {{Inflation-year|UK-GDP}}{{inflation-fn|UK-GDP}}).<ref name="jewishtopwealth" />
== The Beit Trust and other donations == [[Image:ImperialCollegeLondon.jpg|thumb|Imperial College, London]] During his lifetime, Beit made generous donations for scientific work and education. In 1905 he founded a chair of colonial history at the [[University of Oxford]], which is now the ''[[Beit Professor of Commonwealth History|Beit Professor of History of the British Commonwealth]]''.<ref>University of Oxford, Faculty of History. URL http://www.history.ox.ac.uk/staff/postholder/brown_jm.htm</ref> In 1906 he made the donation of two million mark to the stock capital of the ''Hamburgische Wissenschaftliche Stiftung'', a charity dedicated to spend its interest for the benefit of a precursor of the [[University of Hamburg]].
In his will he set up the [[Beit Trust]] through which he bequeathed large sums of money (£1,200,000) for infrastructure development in the former Northern and Southern Rhodesia, later modified to university education and research in [[Zimbabwe]], [[Zambia]] and [[Malawi]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.beittrust.org.uk|title=HOME|website=www.beittrust.org.uk|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref>
Significant infrastructure projects financed by the Trust include the [[Birchenough Bridge]] in the former Southern Rhodesia, named after Sir [[Henry Birchenough]], chairman of the Beit Trust from 1931 until 1937 and whose ashes are buried beneath the structure of the bridge.<ref name="heritage">{{Cite web|url=http://rhodesianheritage.blogspot.com/2010/02/birchenough-bridge.html|title=Our Rhodesian Heritage: Birchenough Bridge|language=en|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> [[Ralph Freeman (1880–1950)|Ralph Freeman]], the bridge's designer, was also the structural designer on the [[Sydney Harbour Bridge]] and consequently the two bridges bear a close resemblance, although Birchenough is only two-thirds as long as the Australian bridge. It was built by Dorman Long and completed in 1935.<ref name=heritage/> At a length of 1,080 feet (329 m) it was the third longest single-arch suspension bridge in the world at the time.
In recognition of his bequests the [[Royal School of Mines]], a faculty of [[Imperial College London]], erected a large memorial to Beit flanking the entrance to its building. The Imperial College residential halls on [[Prince Consort Road]] was named [[Beit Hall]] after him.
== See also == * Sir [[Otto Beit]], 1st Bt (1865–1930), his brother * Sir [[Alfred Lane Beit]], 2nd Bt (1903–1994), his nephew
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *{{cite book |last=Albrecht |first=Henning |year=2012 |title=Alfred Beit: The Hamburg Diamond King |location=Hamburg |publisher=Hamburg University Press |isbn=978-3-943423-01-3 }} : [http://blogs.sub.uni-hamburg.de/hup/products-page/publikationen/108/ online]
{{Authority control}}

page.title: American Chamber of Commerce in Kyrgyzstan

revision.text:
The '''American Chamber of Commerce in Kyrgyzstan''' was founded in cooperation with the [[US State Department]] in 2005 to promote and support the development of international and especially [[United States|American]] business in [[Kyrgyzstan]].
It is the belief of the American Chamber of Commerce that the economic interests of the international and American business community and those of the people of Kyrgyzstan are one.
==See also== * [[Chamber of commerce]] * [[United States Chamber of Commerce]]
==External links== * [http://www.amcham.kg American Chamber of Commerce in Kyrgyzstan] {{Business-org-stub}}
[[Category:American Chambers of commerce]] [[Category:Economy of Kyrgyzstan]]

page.title: App Empire: Make Money, Have a Life, and Let Technology Work for You

revision.text:
{{notability|Books|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox book | name = App Empire: Make Money, Have a Life, and Let Technology Work for You | orig title = | translator = | image = App Empire Cover Art.jpg | caption = | author = [[Chad Mureta]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = [[Self-actualization]], [[Business]], [[Non-fiction]] | publisher = [[John Wiley & Sons]] (USA) | release_date = 2012 (USA) | media_type = Print | pages = 205 p. (US hardcover edition) | isbn = 978-1-118-10787-4 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''App Empire: Make Money, Have a Life, and Let Technology Work for You''''' is a book by [[Chad Mureta]].<ref name=techcrunch>{{cite web|last=Keen|first=Andrew|title=Keen On… Chad Mureta: How Apps Can Change Your Life TCTV|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/03/30/keen-on-chad-mureta-how-apps-can-change-your-life-tctv/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=March 30, 2012}}</ref><ref name=seattlepi>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/lifestyle/blogcritics/article/Book-Review-App-Empire-Make-Money-Have-a-3439261.php |title=Book Review: App Empire - Make Money, Have a Life, and Let Technology Work For You by Chad Mureta |author=Maresca, Joseph S |newspaper=Seattle Post-Intelligencer |date=March 27, 2012}}</ref> It chronicles Mureta's transformation from real estate agent to "appreneur" and provides a non-technical guide to starting an [[mobile app]] business.<ref name=appempire>{{cite book|last=Mureta|first=Chad|title=App Empire: Make Money, Have a Life, and Let Technology Work for You|year=2012|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-1-1181-0787-4|pages=205|url=http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-111810787X,descCd-authorInfo.html}}</ref><ref name=houstonchronicle>[http://www.chron.com/business/press-releases/article/Becoming-an-App-Millionaire-by-Accident-3369875.php Becoming an App Millionaire by Accident]. ''Houston Chronicle''. February 29, 2012.</ref>
==Background== After surviving a car accident that almost ended his life, Mureta borrowed $1,800 from his stepfather to start an app business from his hospital bed.<ref name=houstonchronicle/> Although he had no previous experience in the app or technology fields, he used the money to create his first app, "Fingerprint Security-Pro," which mimics fingerprint-scanning technology. Fingerprint Security-Pro became a bestseller in the [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]], netting more than $50,000.<ref name=huffpo>{{cite news| url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/20/chad-mureta-app-empire-6-million-business-started-in-hospital_n_1607456.html |author=Chun, Janean Chun |title= Chad Mureta Of App Empire Started His $6 Million App Business From A Hospital Bed |newspaper=The Huffington Post |date= June 20, 2012}}</ref> Mureta would go on to found three app companies, developing 46 apps that have been downloaded 35 million times.<ref name=mixergy>{{cite web|last=Warner|first=Andrew|title=Empire Apps: Pulling Off A Comeback In A Brand New Market – Chad Mureta|url=http://mixergy.com/empire-apps-chad-mureta-interview/|publisher=Mixergy|date=August 22, 2011}}</ref><ref name=ferriss>{{cite web|last=Ferriss|first=Tim|title=How to Build an App Empire: Can You Create The Next Instagram?|url=http://www.fourhourworkweek.com/blog/2012/04/22/how-to-build-an-app-empire-can-you-create-the-next-instagram/|publisher=FourHourWorkWeek.com|date=April 22, 2012}}</ref>
==Description== ''App Empire'' is outlined as a how-to guide for those interested in "cash[ing] in on the App gold rush."<ref name=appempire/> The book opens with Mureta's appreneur lifestyle, including scuba diving in [[Fiji]] and learning martial arts in [[Buenos Aires]], while managing his app business from his [[iPhone]].<ref name=appempire/> The book goes onto teach lessons like how to emulate and innovate on existing apps in the [[iOS App Store]], how to hire great programmers and how to generate effective marketing into the app.<ref name=appempire/> Mureta also developed the seven pillars of an app business, which he identifies as:<ref name=appempire/> * Psychology and a Winning Mindset * Market Research * App Development and Maintenance * Analytics and Tweaking * Marketing and Monetization * Team and Systems * Professional Networking
''App Empire'' was featured in [[The Huffington Post]], [[TechCrunch]], ''[[The Houston Chronicle]]'', and Mixergy with ''[[The Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' describing the book as "a wonderful book that explains how to make lots of money formulating, building and promoting popular apps."<ref name=techcrunch/><ref name=seattlepi/><ref name=huffpo/><ref name=mixergy/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://chadmureta.com/ ChadMureta.com] * [https://twitter.com/ChadMureta Chad Mureta] on [[Twitter]]
[[Category:Business books]]

{{distinguish|Benefit corporation}}
'''B Corporation''' certification (also known as '''B Lab''' certification or '''B Corp''' certification) is a private certification issued to [[For-profit corporation|for-profit companies]] by [[B Lab]], a global [[501(c) organization|nonprofit]] organization with offices in the United States, Europe, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and a partnership in Latin America with Sistema B. To be granted and to preserve certification, companies must receive a minimum score on an online assessment for "[[Social impact assessment|social and environmental performance]]", satisfy the requirement that the company integrate [[B Lab]] commitments to [[Stakeholder theory|stakeholders]] into [[By-law|company governing documents]], and pay an annual fee ranging from $500 to $50,000.<ref name="Make It Official">{{cite web |title=B Corporation: Welcome |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://www.bcorporation.net/become-a-b-corp/how-to-become-a-b-corp/make-it-official |accessdate=16 May 2014}}</ref>
As of August 2018, there are over 2,600 certified B Corporations across 150 industries in 60 countries.<ref name="B Corporation: Welcome">{{cite web |title=B Corporation: Welcome |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://www.bcorporation.net/ |accessdate=August, 2018}}</ref>
==Purpose== [[File:Runa B Corp Label.jpg|thumb|Example of a B Corp certification label|193x193px]] The B Lab certification is a third party standard requiring companies to meet [[social sustainability]] and environmental performance standards, meet accountability standards, and to be [[Sustainability reporting|transparent]] to the public according to the score they receive on the assessment. B Lab certification applies to the whole company across all product lines and issue areas. For-profits of all legal [[business entities|business structures]] are eligible for certification.
===Advantages=== * Similar to other [[Companies law|business associations]], certified B Corporations and their employees have access to a number of discounts from outside entities and fellow members.<ref>{{cite web |title=Save Money and Access Services |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://www.bcorporation.net/become-a-b-corp/why-become-a-b-corp/save-money-and-access-services |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> * Academic contributions of loan forgiveness.<ref>{{cite web |title=Loan Assistance Program — Overview |publisher=Columbia Business School |url=http://www8.gsb.columbia.edu/socialenterprise/careers/loanassistance |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Loan Assistance Program – Detailed Summary |publisher=New York University Stern School of Business |url=http://web-docs.stern.nyu.edu/admissions/financial-aid-loan-assistance-program-description-and-policies.pdf |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Loan Forgiveness Program |publisher=[[Yale School of Management]] |url=http://som.yale.edu/our-programs/full-time-mba/admissions/financing-your-mba/loan-forgiveness-program |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref>
===Disadvantages=== * B Lab certification has no legal status.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
===Distinction from benefit corporation=== {{further|Benefit corporation}} * Benefit corporation is a legal status conferred by state law in the US; B Lab certification is issued by a private organisation and has no legislative framework.<ref name="What Are B Corps">{{cite web|title=What Are B Corps |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=https://www.bcorporation.net/what-are-b-corps/legislation |accessdate=16 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517152828/https://www.bcorporation.net/what-are-b-corps/legislation |archivedate=17 May 2014 |df= }}</ref> * B Lab certification is not needed to obtain benefit corporation status.<ref name="What Are B Corps"/> * Legislation for the passage of this corporate legal status has been passed in 30 states, including [[Delaware corporation|Delaware]], whereas B Lab certification is privately issued by an organisation run by people principally issued from the business community.<ref>{{cite web |last=Schwartz |first=Ariel |title=Delaware Just Made It A Whole Lot Easier For Socially Responsible Companies To Exist |publisher=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company & Inc.]] |date=July 23, 2013 |url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/1682654/delaware-just-made-it-a-whole-lot-easier-for-socially-responsible-companies-to-exist |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref>
==Certification process==
===Online assessment=== To obtain a B Corporation certification, a company first completes an online assessment. Companies that earn a minimum score of 80 out of 200 points undergo an assessment review process, essentially a conference call verifying the claims made in their assessment. Companies are required to provide supporting documentation before they are certified.
The assessment covers the company’s entire operation and measures the positive impact of the company in areas of [[Corporate governance|governance]], [[Employee engagement|workers]], [[Community service#Personal benefits of serving|community]], the [[Environmental impact|environment]], as well as the product or service the company provides.<ref>{{cite book |author=Network for Business Innovation and Sustainability |title=B Corporations, Benefit Corporations and Social Purpose Corporations: Launching a New Era of Impact-Driven Companies |publisher=NBIS |date=October 2012 |url=http://nbis.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/ImpactDrivenCompanies_NBIS_Whitepaper_Oct2012.pdf |page=2}}</ref> [[Social business|Socially]] and environmentally-focused business model points ultimately are accrued in their relevant impact area (governance, workers, community or environment).<ref name=giirs>{{cite web |title=GIIRS Governance |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://giirs.org/about-giirs/how-giirs-works/185 |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> Depending on a company's industry, geographic location, and number of employees, the online assessment adjusts the weightings of the question categories to increase its relevancy. For instance, companies with more employees will have a heavier weighting in the workers category, and companies in [[Manufacturing sector|manufacturing]] will have a heavier weighting in the environment category.
To maintain credibility, the B Corporation certification standard operates under principles that are independent, comprehensive, comparable, dynamic, and transparent.<ref>{{cite web |title=AB 361 Assembly Bill - BILL ANALYSIS |publisher=[[California State Assembly]] |url=http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/pub/11-12/bill/asm/ab_0351-0400/ab_361_cfa_20110624_120507_sen_comm.html |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref> B Lab has an established standards advisory council that can independently make decisions with or without the support of B Lab.<ref name=giirs /> As of May 2014, 28 of 30 members were listed by their business affiliation.<ref>{{cite web |title=Standards Advisory Council |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://www.bcorporation.net/what-are-b-corps/the-non-profit-behind-b-corps/standards-advisory-council |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> The council recommends improvements to the B Corp assessment on a biennial basis. There is a 30-day public consultation period before releasing a new version of the B Corporation assessment.<ref name="giirs"/>
Currently the B Corp assessment is its fifth version, with the sixth version scheduled to be released in January 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Corporate Social Responsibility Comes In Many Flavors, Some Not So Tasty |publisher=NonProfit Times Publishing Group |url=http://www.thenonprofittimes.com/news-articles/corporate-social-responsibility-comes-in-many-flavors-some-not-so-tasty/}}</ref>
===Legal requirements=== Certification also requires companies to integrate their stakeholder commitments into the company governing documents. In the United States, the avenue for corporations making the legal amendment to certify will depend on the state they are [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] in. Some states known as "constituency" states will allow for this change in the articles of incorporation, other states, known as "non-constituency states", will not; and many states now have the option of adopting the [[benefit corporation]] legal structure, which also meets B Lab's requirements for B Corp certification.<ref name=howto>{{cite web |title=Corporation Legal Roadmap |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=https://www.bcorporation.net/become-a-b-corp/how-to-become-a-b-corp/legal-roadmap/corporation-legal-roadmap |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> Beyond the corporate model, other for-profit business entities make an amendment of the company by-laws or governing documents. These include: * The establishment of clear wording to "consider stakeholder interests" in company [[Articles of Incorporation|articles of incorporation]] or [[By-law|company by-laws]].<ref name=howto /> * Define "[[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]]" as the employees, the community, the environment, suppliers, customers, and shareholders.<ref name=howto /><ref>See Boatright (2006) and Johnstone and Lionais (2004).</ref> * No prioritization of one stakeholder over another.<ref>{{cite web |title= OLR Backgrounder: Social Enterprise and the Benefit Corporation |publisher=State of Connecticut, Office of Legislative Research |url=http://www.cga.ct.gov/2013/rpt/2013-R-0260.htm}}</ref> * Allowing for the company's values to exist under new management, investors, or ownership.<ref name=howto /><ref>See Lencioni (July 2002).</ref>
However, B Lab certification allows the company bylaws to remain secret.
==International adoption== In September 2018, there were over 2,000 certified B Corporations across 130 industries in 50 countries,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/deborahsweeney/2018/09/13/how-b-corporations-change-the-way-entrepreneurs-think-about-profit-and-consumers/#405f3d5c3470|title=How B Corporations Change The Way Entrepreneurs Think About Profit And Consumers|last=Sweeney|first=Deborah|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref> including [[Canada]] (78 companies), [[Australia]], [[South Africa]], and [[Afghanistan]].<ref name="B Corporation: Welcome"/> The most active community outside of the United States is '''Sistema B'''.<ref>{{cite journal |title= The double bottom line: Profit and social benefit |journal=Business Horizons |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0007681313001729 | doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2013.10.001 |volume=57 |pages=11–20}}</ref> Since 2012, Sistema B has been the adaptation of the B Corps movement in [[Latin America]], including in [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Chile]], [[Uruguay]] and [[Colombia]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Camacho |first=Manuel Antonio |title=In Just a Few Months, Sistema B (AKA: B Corp) Finds Fertile Ground for Social Enterprises in Latin America |url=http://www.nextbillion.net/blogpost.aspx?blogid=2908 |date=August 15, 2012 |publisher=NextBillion.net |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> This non-profit adapts proprietary certifications and evaluation metrics and modifies both to the context of each country. B Lab also assists Sistema B in incorporating a [[benefit corporation]] distinction into local legal systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialenterprisebuzz.com/2012/09/26/b-lab-and-sistema-b-partner-to-take-b-corps-global/|title=B Lab and Sistema B Partner to take B Corps Global|last=Ip|first=Melissa|date=September 26, 2012|website=|publisher=Social Enterprise Buzz|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628141813/http://www.socialenterprisebuzz.com/2012/09/26/b-lab-and-sistema-b-partner-to-take-b-corps-global/|archive-date=28 June 2017|dead-url=|accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Low-profit limited liability company]] * [[Social purpose corporation]]
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last=André|first=Rae|title=Assessing the Accountability of the Benefit Corporation: Will This New Gray Sector Organization Enhance Corporate Social Responsibility?|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|year=2012|volume=110|issue=1|pages=133–150|doi=10.1007/s10551-012-1254-1}} *{{cite journal |last=Boatright |first=John R. |title=What's Wrong—and What's Right—with Stakeholder Management |journal=Journal of Private Enterprise |volume=21 |issue=2 |year=2006 |pages=106–130 |url=http://www.apee.org/pdf/BoatrightSpec.pdf}} * {{cite book |editor1-last=Davis |editor1-first=Kevin E. |editor2-last=Fisher |editor2-first=Angelina |editor3-last=Kingsbury |editor3-first=Benedict |editor4-last=Merry |editor4-first=Sally Engle |title=Governance by Indicators: Global Power through Classification and Rankings |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=2012 |isbn=978-0-19-965824-4}} * {{cite journal |last=Deskins |first=Michael R. |title=Benefit Corporation Legislation, Version 1.0—A Breakthrough in Stakeholder Rights? |journal=Lewis and Clark Law Review |volume=15 |year=2011 |page=1047}} * {{cite journal |last1=Johnstone |first1=Harvey |last2=Lionais |first2=Doug |title=Depleted communities and community business entrepreneurship: revaluing space through place |journal=Entrepreneurship & Regional Development |volume=16 |issue=3 |year=2004 |pages=217–233 |doi=10.1080/0898562042000197117}} *{{cite journal|last=Lacovara|first=Christopher|title=Strange Creatures: A Hybrid Approach to Fiduciary Duty in Benefit Corporations|journal=Columbia Business Law Review|year=2011|pages=815–880}} * * {{cite journal|last=Lencioni |first=Patrick M. |authorlink=Patrick Lencioni |title=Make Your Values Mean Something |magazine=[[Harvard Business Review]] |date=July 2002 |url=http://www.brynmawr.edu/businessworkshops/management/documents/Lencioni-Makeyourvaluesmeansomething.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309021800/http://www.brynmawr.edu/businessworkshops/management/documents/Lencioni-Makeyourvaluesmeansomething.pdf |archivedate=2014-03-09 |df= }} * {{cite journal|last=Reiser |first=Dana Brakman |title=Benefit Corporations—A Sustainable Form of Organization? |journal=[[Wake Forest Law Review]] |volume=46 |year=2011 |page=591 |url=http://wakeforestlawreview.com/benefit-corporations%E2%80%94a-sustainable-form-of-organization |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140424113441/http://wakeforestlawreview.com/benefit-corporations%E2%80%94a-sustainable-form-of-organization |archivedate=2014-04-24 |df= }}
== External links == *{{official website|http://www.bcorporation.net}} *[http://benefitcorp.net Benefit Corporation Information Center]

revision.text:
{{Infobox congressman |name= Butler Ames |image name= Butler Ames Massachusetts Congressman.png |imagesize = 175px |smallimage= |caption = Butler Ames circa 1908{{Citation| title =Who's who in State Politics, 1908 | page = 10. | publisher = Practical Politics | location = Boston, Massachusetts |year= 1908}} |state = [[Massachusetts]] |district = {{ushr|MA|5|5th}} |term_start = March 4, 1903 |term_end = March 3, 1913 |predecessor= [[William Shadrach Knox]] |successor = [[John Jacob Rogers]] |order2 = |office2 = Member of the
Massachusetts House of Representatives |term_start2= 1897 |term_end2 = 1899 |predecessor2= |successor2 = |order3 = |office3 = [[City of Boston]] [[City council|Common Council]]
|term_start3= |term_end3 = |predecessor3= |successor3 = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |birth_date= {{Birth date|1871|8|22}} |birth_place= [[Lowell, Massachusetts|Lowell]], [[Massachusetts]] |religion = |alma_mater= [[Phillips Exeter Academy]], [[United States Military Academy]] at West Point, [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] |occupation = mechanical and electrical engineer |death_date= {{death date and age|1954|11|6|1871|8|22}} |death_place= [[Tewksbury, Massachusetts|Tewksbury]], [[Massachusetts]] |restingplace=[[Hildreth Cemetery#Hildreth Family Cemetery|Hildreth Family Cemetery]]
[[Lowell, Massachusetts]] |spouse= |branch = [[United States Army]] |rank = [[Lieutenant Colonel]] |serviceyears = 1894, 1898 - 1899 |battles = [[Spanish–American War]] }} '''Butler Ames''' (August 22, 1871 – November 6, 1954) was an American politician, engineer, soldier and businessman. He was the son of [[Adelbert Ames]] and grandson of [[Benjamin Butler (politician)|Benjamin Franklin Butler]], both decorated generals in the [[Union Army]] during the [[American Civil War]]. Born in [[Lowell, Massachusetts]], Ames attended the public schools and [[Phillips Exeter Academy]], in [[Exeter, New Hampshire]], and graduated from the [[United States Military Academy]] at West Point in 1894. He resigned from the [[United States Army]] after appointment as second lieutenant to the Eleventh Regiment, United States Infantry; took a postgraduate course at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], was a member of [[Theta Xi]] fraternity, and graduated in 1896 as a mechanical and electrical engineer. Ames engaged in manufacturing; served as a member of the common council of Lowell in 1896; like his father, he re-joined the Army during the [[Spanish–American War]] and was commissioned lieutenant and adjutant of the Sixth Regiment, Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry; appointed acting engineer officer of the Second Army Corps under [[William Montrose Graham, Jr.|General Graham]], in addition to his duties as adjutant. He was promoted to lieutenant colonel in August 1898; served as civil administrator of the Arecibo district of [[Puerto Rico]] until November 1898. [[File:Brazilian Aeronautical Commission.JPG|thumb|left|Ames' former residence in [[Washington, D.C.]]]] Ames became a member of the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]] 1897–1899; elected as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] to the [[58th United States Congress|Fifty-eighth]] and to the four succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1903 – March 3, 1913); was not a candidate for renomination in 1912; resumed manufacturing pursuits; president of [[United States Cartridge Company]], and treasurer of Heinze Electrical Co. of Lowell; at time of death was treasurer and a director of Wamesit Power Co. of Lowell, Massachusetts; director of Union Land and Grazing Co., Colorado Springs, Colorado, and vice president and a director of Ames Textile in Lowell. Ames was completely taken with [[Villa del Balbianello]] when he visited Europe for the first time in 1912, and he determined to purchase the Villa. He succeeded in 1919, beautifully restoring the Villa. On a Dictaphone Tape he tells the story (also a short autobiography). The Tape was transcribed, and his greater family published it in book form: "Butler Ames and the Villa Balbianello, Lake Como, Italy, An American Oral History." Essays and introductions by Evelyn Ames, Pauline Ames Plimpton, Ezio Antonini, Sarah and George Plimpton plus period photographs and the illustrated Guest Book 1920 to 1970 was added. The book was edited by Oakes Plimpton and printed by Hobblebush Press, 2009, available through Amazon Books or Oakes Plimpton, 67 Coolidge Road, Arlington, MA 02476. Ames died in [[Tewksbury, Massachusetts]] in 1954, at the age of 83. He is buried, along with his father, grandfather and extended family, in the Hildreth family cemetery, behind the main cemetery on Hildreth Street in Lowell.[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/7500803 Butler Ames (1871–1954) - Find A Grave Memorial] His heirs sold Villa del Balbianello in 1974 to [[Guido Monzino]].[http://www.friendsoffai.org/where-we-are_villa-del-balbianello.php "Villa del Balbianello" ''Friends of FAI''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610122217/http://www.friendsoffai.org/where-we-are_villa-del-balbianello.php |date=2016-06-10 }} retrieved May 20, 2016 ==References== {{Bioguide}} {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * [http://asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss358_bioghist.html Ames Family Papers 1812-2007] *''Who's who in State Politics, 1908'' Practical Politics (1908) p. 265. {{CongBio|A000173}} *[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/ames.html#937.43.71 Butler Ames entry] at [[The Political Graveyard]] {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox |state= Massachusetts |district= 5 |before= [[William S. Knox]] |after= [[John Jacob Rogers]] |years= March 4, 1903 – March 3, 1913}} {{s-end}} {{USRepMA}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ames, Butler}} [[Category:1871 births]] [[Category:1954 deaths]] [[Category:Butler–Ames family]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Spanish–American War]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Massachusetts House of Representatives]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Massachusetts]] [[Category:Politicians from Lowell, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Phillips Exeter Academy alumni]] [[Category:United States Army colonels]] [[Category:United States Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:Massachusetts Republicans]] [[Category:Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]]

{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{primary sources|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = CRISIL Limited | image = CRISIL Logo-wikipedia.jpg | type = Public company | traded_as = {{BSE|500092}}
{{NSE|CRISIL}} | foundation = 1987{{cite web|url=http://crisil.com/about-crisil/our-history.html |title=CRISIL - History |publisher=crisil.com |accessdate=20 November 2013}} | founder = | location = [[Mumbai]], [[Maharashtra]], India | caption = | key_people = Ms. Ashu Suyash
{{small|(MD & CEO)}} | num_employees = | industry = | services = Ratings, research, risk and policy advisory | revenue = {{increase}} {{INRConvert|11106|m}} (December 2013){{cite web|url=http://www.bseindia.com/bseplus/AnnualReport/500092/5000921213.pdf|title=December 2013 results|publisher=BSE|accessdate=31 December 2013}} | net_income = {{profit}} {{INRConvert|2978.2|m}} (December 2013) | assets = | operating_income = {{profit}} {{INRConvert|3199.5|m}} (December 2013) | equity = }} '''CRISIL''' (formerly '''C'''redit '''R'''ating '''I'''nformation '''S'''ervices of '''I'''ndia '''L'''imited) is a global analytical company providing ratings, research, and risk and policy advisory services.{{cite web|url=http://crisil.com/about-crisil/about-overview.html|title=: CRISIL - Overview : |publisher=crisil.com |accessdate=20 November 2013}} CRISIL’s majority [[shareholder]] is [[Standard & Poor's]], a division of [[McGraw Hill Financial]] and provider of financial market intelligence.{{cite web|url=http://crisil.com/about-crisil/about-overview.html |title=: About CRISIL: |publisher=crisil.com |accessdate=20 November 2013}} As of December 2013, the company has revenue of {{INRConvert|11106|m}}, net income of {{INRConvert|2978.2|m}} and operating income of {{INRConvert|3199.5|m}}. == News == The Union Minister for Finance and Corporate Affairs Shri [[Arun Jaitley]] launched [[CriSidEx]] , India’s first sentiment index for micro and small enterprises (MSEs) developed jointly by CRISIL and SIDBI.{{cite web| url =https://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/msmes-get-a-boost-jaitley-launches-india-s-first-sentiment-index-crisidex-118020400064_1.html|title=MSMEs get a boost: Jaitley launches India's first sentiment index CriSidEx |publisher =[[Business Standard]] |date =February 4, 2018}} CriSidEx is a composite index based on a diffusion index of 8 parameters and measures MSE business sentiment on a scale of 0 (extremely negative) to 200 (extremely positive).{{cite web| url =https://www.livemint.com/Money/TxoEaqkRbBp0FvlZs2ahsI/Jaitley-launches-CriSidEx-says-economy-witnessing-a-phase-o.html|title=Jaitley launches CriSidEx, says economy witnessing a phase of consolidation |publisher =[[LiveMint]]|author=Komal Gupta |date =February 3, 2018}} CriSidEx will have two indices, one for the 'survey quarter' and another for 'next quarter' once a trend emerges after few rounds of the survey, providing independent time series data. The parametric feedback was captured through a survey of 1100 MSEs in November –December. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Standard & Poor's]] [[Category:Financial services companies based in Mumbai]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Market research]] [[Category:Credit rating agencies in India]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Magazine | category = [[Cement]] | publisher = Association of publishers | country = [[Russia]] | firstdate = 1901 | website = https://web.archive.org/web/20090130051525/http://cemcom.ru:80/ | issn = 1607-8837 }} '''''Cement and its Applications''''' was founded over a hundred years ago and is a privately owned independent [[trade magazine]] dealing with the problems of production and application of cement in Russia, in all the newly independent states on the territory of the former USSR and in other countries of the world. The magazine, which is the only cement specialist Russian-language periodical, works in close co-operation with cement plants and holding companies, equipment manufacturers, producers of concretes, dry construction mixes and other cement products users, as well as with research and design institutes and institutions of higher education, all of those being its major subscribers.
Great attention is paid to the problems of cement plants development, capital flow and economic issues of Russian and international industry.
The magazine is distributed all over Russia, CIS countries and abroad. It is published bimonthly with news and analytical materials in English.
[[Category:Russian business magazines]] [[Category:Professional and trade magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1901]] [[Category:Cement industry]]
{{trade-mag-stub}} {{architecture-stub}} {{Europe-business-mag-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2013}} {{infobox legislation | short_title = Commerce Act 1986 | legislature = [[New Zealand Parliament]] | image = Coat of arms of New Zealand.svg | imagesize = 180px | long_title = To promote competition within markets in New Zealand | introduced_by = | administered_by = | datepassed = | royal_assent = 28 April 1986 | date_commenced = | amendments = 2008 | related = | repeals = | status = Current }} The '''Commerce Act 1986''' is a statute of [[New Zealand]]. It prohibits conduct that restricts competition and purchase of shares or assets where that would lessen competition in a market.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comcom.govt.nz/the-legislation/|title=Commerce Act 1986|publisher=[[Commerce Commission]]}}</ref>
As well as generally governing markets, the Act gives the [[Commerce Commission]] particular powers in relation to services provided by electricity lines businesses, gas pipeline businesses and airports.
==See also== * [[Commerce Commission]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1986/0005/latest/DLM87623.html Commerce Act 1986]
[[Category:New Zealand Statutes]] [[Category:Competition law]] [[Category:1986 in New Zealand law]] [[Category:Business in New Zealand]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2405:205:A120:5BFA:0:0:1C29:50A4|2405:205:A120:5BFA:0:0:1C29:50A4]] ([[User talk:2405:205:A120:5BFA:0:0:1C29:50A4|talk]]) to last version by InternetArchiveBot
revision.text:
'''Consumer relationship systems''' ('''CRS''') are specialized [[customer relationship management]] (CRM) [[software]] applications that are used to handle a company's dealings with its customers.<ref name ="Insight44-50">[http://www.nxtbook.com/nxtbooks/cmp/cmi_200709/index.php ICMI Customer Management Insight Magazine, September 2007, pp 44–50], Retrieved 11 January 2012</ref>
Current consumer relationship systems integrate the [[software]] with telephone and call recording systems as well as with corporate systems for input and reporting. Customers can provide input from the company's website directly into the CRS. These systems are popular because they can deliver the 'voice of the consumer' that contributes to product quality improvement and that ultimately increases corporate profits.<ref name ="Insight44-50" />
Consumer relationship systems that provide automated support as well as advanced systems may have [[artificial intelligence]] (AI) interfaces that can extract and analyse [[data]] collected, or handle basic questions and complaints.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Smith| first1=S.E.|title= What is Consumer Relationship System? |date= |publisher= WiseGeek.net|url= http://www.wisegeek.net/what-is-consumer-relationship-system.htm|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref>
==History== The first CRS was developed in the 1980s. In 1981 Michael Wilke and Robert Thornton founded Wilke/Thornton, Inc in [[Columbus, Ohio]], to develop new CRS software.<ref>[http://www.wilke-thornton.com/WTI/Pages/products.html Wilke/Thornton, Inc Products] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820093347/http://www.wilke-thornton.com/WTI/Pages/products.html |date=2008-08-20 }} Retrieved 11 January 2012</ref>
==See also== * [[ECRM]] * [[Business intelligence]] * [[Customer experience]] * [[Customer intelligence]] * [[Customer service]] – contains ISO standards * [[Customer value maximization]] * [[Enterprise relationship management]] (ERM) * [[Sales force management system]] * [[Sales intelligence]] * [[Sales process engineering]]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Business intelligence]] [[Category:Data management]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Globalize/US|date=March 2013}} {{More footnotes|date=July 2010}} }}
[[File:Workers At Dusk, GEC, Chittagong.jpg|thumb|Construction labors in [[Chittagong]], [[Bangladesh]].]] '''Day labor''' (or '''day labour''' in [[American and British English spelling differences|Commonwealth spelling]]) is work done where the worker is hired and paid one day at a time, with no promise that more work will be available in the future. It is a form of [[contingent work]].
==Types== [[File:Mednyánszky, László - Day Labourer.jpg|thumb|upright|''Day Labourer'' (painting by [[László Mednyánszky]])]] [[File:Tagelöhnerhaus qtl1.jpg|thumb|left|House of a day labourer in the {{Interlanguage link multi|Open-air museum Beuren|de|3=Freilichtmuseum Beuren}}, Germany]] Day [[laborer]]s find work through three common routes.
Firstly, some [[employment agency|employment agencies]] specialize in very short-term contracts for manual labor most often in construction, factories, offices, and manufacturing. These companies usually have offices where workers can arrive and be assigned to a job on the spot, as they are available.
Secondly, a manager looking for additional labor to fill an unexpected change in plans is presented with a problem of finding the needed quantity of labor with the right skills. Imagine the magnitude of the task of looking for workers, on the side of the street or by calling various employment agencies, who can verify that they are journeyman asphalt rakers, typists, programmers, etc. The benefit of representation is applied to both the labor and employer.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Freeman |first1=R. |last2= Medoff |first2=J. |title=What Do Unions Do? |location=New York |work=Basic Books, Inc. |year=1984 |url=http://www.uschinalabor.org/docs%5CWhat%20Do%20Unions%20Do_E.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref><ref>http://ecsocman.edu.ru/db/msg/22917.html</ref> Labor is given a source of recourse to achieve a safe work environment free of favoritism and arbitrary work assignments. Employers benefit from organized labor training programs, benefit plans, dispute resolution<ref>[http://www.laborerslocal185.com/disputes_resolutions.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917131935/http://www.laborerslocal185.com/disputes_resolutions.htm |date=September 17, 2008 }}</ref> and a labor supply meeting most employers labor demand at most any time or place. The benefit of a labor supply arriving at a specified time and location within less than a day's notice is reduced overhead resources.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Ehrenburg |first1=R. |last2=Smith |first2=R. |title=Modern Labor Economics: Theory and Public Policy, 8th Edition |work== Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations |year=2003 |page=132 |ISBN=0-321-30503-5 |url=http://homepage.ntu.edu.tw/~liuyc/LaborPaper/ch4sup.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref><ref>http://ecsocman.edu.ru/db/msg/5524.html</ref>
Thirdly and less formally, workers meet at well-known locations, usually public street corners or commercial parking lots, and wait for [[building contractor]]s, landscapers, home owners and small business owners, and other potential employers to offer work. Much of this work is in small residential [[construction]] or landscaping.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/10/national/10depot.html |title=Day Laborer Battle Runs Outside Home Depot |publisher= New York Times}}</ref> These workers earn, on average, $8–$10 an hour. The media and a study by [[UCLA]] portrays day laborers as being illegal immigrants from [[Mexico]] and [[Central America]],<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.uclalumni.net/eNewsletters/Connect/Feb06/DayLabor.cfm?email=G2II ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081023171616/http://www.uclalumni.net/eNewsletters/Connect/Feb06/DayLabor.cfm?email=G2II |date=October 23, 2008 }}</ref> who otherwise can't get work due to current employment regulations.<ref>http://uscode.house.gov/download/pls/Title_08.txt</ref> Other research has found that day laborers are not typically illegal immigrants, many even being citizens of the US, and that day labor is often a transition to full-time work.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.daylaborinfo.org/research.aspx |title=Research |publisher=Daylaborinfo.org}}</ref>
==Day labor in the United States== day labor (or labour in commonwealth spelling ) is work done where the worker is hired and paid one day at time , with no promise that more work will be available in the future. it is a form of contingent work. Informal day labor is not new to the United States, and day laborers are not always [[migrant workers]] in many cases. In his study of day laborers in [[Atlanta]], Terry Easton interviews [[white people|white]] and [[black people|black]] day laborers in addition to [[Hispanic]] workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://southernspaces.org/2007/geographies-hope-and-despair-atlantas-african-american-latino-and-white-day-laborers |title=Terry Easton, Geographies of Hope and Despair: Atlanta's African American, Latino, and White Day Laborers |publisher=Southernspaces.org |date=2007-12-21 |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> Many other metropolitan areas still have non-immigrant day laborers, and many other large and small cities have immigrant day laborers from a variety of countries, including [[Mongolia]], [[Poland]], [[Russia]], [[Brazil]], Central and South America, and countries in [[Africa]]. Non-immigrant informal day labor, seen in many cities, does not generate the controversy or calls to police and local government seen when immigrant day laborers gather to wait for work.{{citation needed|date=November 2010}}
Unorganized day labor creates real problems for day laborers: 1 in 3 corner day laborers have experienced theft of wages in the past two months; 1 in 5 experienced a serious worksite injury in the past year.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Low wages and poor working conditions, employer abuse, and lack of insurance for work related accidents is common.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.issuelab.com/browse/browse_pub.php?pub_id=478 |title=Speak for Yourself: What Girls Say about What Girls Need |publisher=IssueLab |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref><ref>Ordonez Juan Thomas (2015) Jornalero: Being a Day Laborer in the USA. University of California Press</ref>
Numerous complaints are made about immigrant day laborers. These include loitering, noise, crime and rushing cars of potential employers in parking lots. Cities and counties have tried a variety of solutions with varied success. Some municipalities and communities have supported workers' efforts to organize themselves into democratically run [[day labor centers|workers' centers]], designated areas, and [[organization]]s to defend [[labor rights|workers' rights]] in general. Workers' Centers of this kind date back at least 18 years{{when|date=March 2014}} to [[Los Angeles]]. Other municipalities have targeted day labor sites for aggressive enforcement of immigration laws.<ref>http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/news/articles/1017arpaioimmigration1017.html</ref>
Though united in their commitment to the rights of [[migrant worker|immigrant workers]], NDLON and the Day Labor Research Institute represent two very different models of day labor center. NDLON represents the "social service agency model" and the Institute the "day laborer designed model."<ref name=autogenerated3>http://daylaborinfo.org/Documents/Comparing%20Day%20Labor%20Center%20Models.pdf</ref> These different models of day labor centers may yield markedly different results that reflect the different goals of each model.<ref name=autogenerated3 />
Problems when workers' centers are established are also common: day laborers often continue to congregate in large numbers on the streets surrounding the day labor centers, refusing to leave the street and use the center;<ref>{{cite web |last=Svensson |first=Lynn |title=Best Practices for Day Labor Centers" Planning |publisher=American Planning Association |date=April 2006:10 |url=http://myapa.planning.org/planning/member/2006apr/daylaborside.htm?project=Print}}</ref> new problems can be created, including new crowds of homeless and substance abusers loitering near the center after hours, and large numbers of day laborers drawn from other areas to the streets surrounding the centers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://daylaborinfo.org/Documents/disorder_at_daylaborsites.pdf |format=PDF |title=Disorder at Day Laborer Sites |publisher=Daylaborinfo.org}}</ref> Low levels of work at the centers, low wages, and problems with the job distribution system are also common.<ref>http://daylaborinfo.org/Documents/FinalOneStopReport.pdf</ref>
==See also== * [[Temporary work]] * [[Peon]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
*Easton, Terry. "[http://southernspaces.org/2007/geographies-hope-and-despair-atlantas-african-american-latino-and-white-day-laborers Geographies of Hope and Despair: Atlanta's African American, Latino, and White Day Laborers]." ''Southern Spaces'', December 21, 2007. http://southernspaces.org/2007/geographies-hope-and-despair-atlantas-african-american-latino-and-white-day-laborers *Odem, Mary. "[http://southernspaces.org/2006/global-lives-local-struggles-latin-american-immigrants-atlanta Global Lives, Local Struggles: Latin American Immigrants in Atlanta.]" ''Southern Spaces,'' May 19, 2006. http://southernspaces.org/2006/global-lives-local-struggles-latin-american-immigrants-atlanta *Sanchez, George. "[http://southernspaces.org/2007/latinos-american-south-and-future-us-race-relations Latinos, the American South, and the Future of U.S. Race Relations.]" ''Southern Spaces,'' April 26, 2007. http://southernspaces.org/2007/latinos-american-south-and-future-us-race-relations *Svensson, Lynn. [http://www.daylaborinfo.org/Documents/Comparing%20Day%20Labor%20Center%20Models.pdf Comparing Solutions: An Overview of Day Labor Programs]. ''Day Labor Research Institute,'' August, 2004. *Guerette, Rob T. [http://daylaborinfo.org/Documents/disorder_at_daylaborsites.pdf Disorder at Day Laborer Sites]. ''U.S Dept. of Justice, Office of Community Oriented Policing Services, Problem Oriented Guides for Police, Problem-Specific Guides Series, No. 44,'' October, 2006. *Foster, Meghan. [http://daylaborinfo.org/Documents/Failing%20to%20Deliver.pdf Failing to Deliver: One-Stop Employment Centers]. ''Day Labor/Jobs Project of the Chicago Coalition for the Homeless,'' 2004 *Torres, Gustavo. [http://daylaborinfo.org/Documents/7.pdf From Services to Activism: How Latino Day Laborers and Domestic Workers are Advocating for Themselves]. ''From Services to Activism: How Latino Day Laborers and Domestic Workers are Advocating for Themselves, NYU/Wagner, Leadership for a Changing World, Research and Documentation Component, Research Center for Leadership in Action,'' September, 2003.
==External links== ===Organizations=== * [http://www.daylaborstation.org/Resources.htm Public Architecture's Day Labor Station] * [http://www.sol-plus.net/jornaleros.htm Library Service to Day Laborers: Biblio/webliography] * [http://www.casa-latina.org/ Casa Latina] * [http://www.issuelab.com/search/search.php?r=25&q=day+labor Issue Lab: Day Labor] * [http://www.daylaborinfo.org Day Labor Research Institute]
===In film and television=== * [https://www.pbs.org/independentlens/theworkers/ PBS The Workers documentary] * [https://www.pbs.org/pov/pov2004/farmingville/ PBS Farmingville documentary] * [http://www.daylaborthemovie.com/ Day Labor, a short comedy satirizing corporate America through the experience of two laborers] * [http://www.thejobtheshort.com/ The Job, an award-winning comic short]

added link to "desktop outsourcing" in "IT as a service", removed orphan template
revision.text:
'''Desktop outsourcing''' is the process in which an [[organization]] contracts a third party to maintain and manage parts of its [[IT infrastructure]]. Contracts vary in depth and can range from [[Computer maintenance|Computer hard]]- and [[software maintenance]] to [[Desktop virtualisation]], [[SaaS]]-implementations and [[Helpdesk]] operation. It is estimated, that 32% of U.S. and Canadian IT organisations make use of desktop outsourcing in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bekker|first1=Scott|title=Should You Outsource Your Help Desk?|url=http://redmondmag.com/Articles/2014/09/01/Should-You-Outsource.aspx?Page=3|website=Redmond Magazine|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> Recent market reports suggest the adoption of [[BYOD]] policies to allow the end-user a free choice of devices in their working environment may increase this market share.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Desktop Outsourcing Market 2012-2016|url=http://www.researchandmarkets.com/research/xbv6lv/global_desktop|website=Research and Markets|publisher=TechNavio|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Desktop-Outsourcing im Trend|url=http://www.itadministrator.de/themen/virtualisierung/111035.html|website=ITAdministrator.de|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref>
==Viability== Justification for desktop outsourcing could include shifting focus and energy to areas of core competency, reducing staffing costs, and the routine maintenance, upgrades, and repairs associated with managing multitudes of PC systems and servers. (Applegate et al. 2007). Managers may also seek desktop outsourcing as a method of simplifying organisational structures to cut costs associated with them.<ref name="dfcw">{{cite web|last1=Friedlander|first1=David|title=Why outsource desktop management?|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/opinion/Why-outsource-desktop-management|website=ComputerWeekly.com|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> For smaller companies it might also be more viable financially to outsource their desktop at a set price per machine, rather than creating an entire internal IT department.<ref name="littman">{{cite web|last1=Littman|first1=Dan|title=Outsourcing the desktop|url=http://www.infoworld.com/article/2655241/techology-business/outsourcing-the-desktop.html|website=InfoWorld.com|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> Recent market growth can also be attributed to the decreasing price of hardware, making replacement more favourable than repairs.<ref name="dfcw" /> Possible risks when desktop outsourcing are ensuring continued support for old a unique systems the company depends on, specifically if any of the systems in question were internally developed.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Stephen|title=Managing Risk in Outsourcing: The Strategy|url=http://www.sourcingmag.com/managing-risk-in-outsourcing-the-strategy/|website=SourcingMag.com|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> This may cause the contractor to be unable to fulfil their contractual obligations, as in the case of the US Navy outsourcing their IT systems to EDS in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Ephraim|title=Painful lessons from IT outsourcing gone bad|url=http://www.infoworld.com/article/2652801/outsourcing/painful-lessons-from-it-outsourcing-gone-bad.html|website=InfoWorld.com|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref>
==Market situation== A 2012 TechNavio market report forecasts that the desktop outsourcing market will grow by 4.65% yearly, between 2012 and 2016. [[Atos]], [[Computer Sciences Corporation|CSC]], [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]] and [[IBM]] are considered the leading desktop outsourcing vendors for that time frame.<ref>{{cite web|title=Research and Markets: Global Desktop Outsourcing Market 2012-2016 Research Report|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/research-markets-global-desktop-outsourcing-104100265.html|website=Yahoo Finance|publisher=BusinessWire|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> A [[Gartner]] report from 2013, however, considers the desktop outsourcing market to be in decline, with growth only occurring on the Latin American and Asia/Pacific markets.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gartner Says Worldwide IT Outsourcing Market to Reach $288 Billion in 2013|url=http://www.gartner.com/newsroom/id/2550615|website=gartner.com}}</ref>
==Examples== * While consolidating School Districts in 2003, New York city brought in Dell to assess and consolidate their IT systems. At the time it was unclear how many devices actually existed in the network. Being largely successful, this netted Dell a $20 million yearly contract to keep on managing the School Districts systems.<ref name="littman" /> * NASA's Kennedy Space Center had its IT services, approximately 22,000 devices, outsourced in 1998 for $30 million a year on a 3-year contract.<ref name="gaogov">{{cite web|title=DESKTOP OUTSOURCING: Positive Results Reported, but Analyses Could Be Strengthened|url=http://www.gao.gov/assets/240/234095.pdf|website=gao.gov|publisher=United States General Accounting Office|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> * The US Treasury outsourced their 1643 desktop and 700 portable seats in 1999 for around $27 million yearly.<ref name="gaogov" />
== References == {{reflist}} * Corporate Information Strategy and Management. Applegate, Lynda, Austin, Robert, McFarlan, Warren F. (2007). New York: McGraw Hill Companies, Inc. {{ISBN|0-07-063584-6}} * Littman, Dan. "Outsourcing the desktop: Outsourcing desktop management can shave costs while bringing relief to an assortment of infrastructure management headaches". IDG Publishing Network, Inc. 6 February 2006. 18 April 2008.<[http://www.infoworld.com/article/06/02/06/74669_06FEoutdesk_3.html]>. * Gartner. "Desktop Outsourcing". gartner.com <[http://blogs.gartner.com/it-glossary/desktop-outsourcing/]>.
== External links == *[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-14027181_ITM Outsourcing the desktop - Outsourcing desktop management can shave costs while bringing relief to an assortment of infrastructure management headaches.(case studies on outsourcing)]
